review.title: Reasoning within Fuzzy Description Logics
review.abstract: Description Logics (DLs) are suitable, well-known, logics for managing structured knowledge. They allow reasoning about individuals and well defined concepts, i.e., set of individuals with common properties. The experience in using DLs in applications has shown that in many cases we would like to extend their capabilities. In particular, their use in the context of Multimedia Information Retrieval (MIR) leads to the convincement that such DLs should allow the treatment of the inherent imprecision in multimedia object content representation and retrieval. In this paper we will present a fuzzy extension of ALC, combining Zadeh's fuzzy logic with a classical DL. In particular, concepts becomes fuzzy and, thus, reasoning about imprecise concepts is supported. We will define its syntax, its semantics, describe its properties and present a constraint propagation calculus for reasoning in it.

metadata.title: Reasoning within Fuzzy Description Logics

sections.text: In this paper, we will present a blurred extension of ALC that combines Zadeh's blurred logic with a classical DL. Specifically, concepts are blurred, thus supporting thinking about imprecise concepts; we will define their syntax, semantics, describe their properties, and represent a constraint propagation calculation for thinking in them.1. Introduction The depiction of uncertainty and inaccuracy has received considerable attention in the artificial intelligence community, in an attempt to expand existing knowledge representation systems to deal with the imperfect nature of real information (which is more the rule than the exception).An impressive piece of work has been done in recent decades, which has led to a number of concepts being investigated, a number of problems being identified, and a number of solutions being developed (Bacchus, 1990; Dubois & Prade, 1996; Kruse, Schwecke, & Heinsohn, 1991; Pearl, 1988).

In fact, classical DLi systems are usually insufficient. (Nowadays, a whole family of knowledge representation systems has been built using DLs that differ in terms of their expressiveness, complexity, and completeness of their algorithms.) Experience in the use of DLs in applications has also shown that we want to expand their representation and thinking capabilities. (Peltason, 1991; Brachman, 1992; Hollunder, 1991a; Horrocks, 1998.) The use of DLs in applications has also shown that we want to expand their representation and thinking capabilities, especially the use of DLs in the context of retrieval information (MIR) points to the need to expand DLs with capabilities that enable the treatment of inherent imprecision in multimedia objects (Meghini & Straccia, 1996; Meghini, Sebastiani, Straccia, 1998).

While these probabilistic extensions increase the applicability of DLs, they do not address the question of arguing about individuals and imprecise concepts, since imprecise knowledge and uncertain knowledge are "orthogonal" (Dubois & Prade, 1994). Furthermore, arguing in a probabilistic framework is generally a more difficult task from a computational point of view than the relative non-probabilistic case, and in most cases lacks complete axiomatization (Halpern, 1990; Roth, 1996). Consequently, the computer-related problems need to be addressed carefully (Koller et al., 1997). We will proceed as follows: In the following section, we will first introduce ALC, which we will extend to the ambiguous case, and discuss some properties in Section 4, while in Section 5 we will outline a limitation on the propagation of calculations for the argument.

A fuzzy set S in relation to a universe U is characterized by a membership function µS: U → [0, 1], the assignment of an S membership level, µS (u), to each element u in U. µS (u) gives us an estimate of the affiliation from u to S. Typically, if µS (u) = 1 then definitely belongs to S, while µS (u) = 0.8 means that u is "likely" an element of S.

The following proposition follows from (Lee, 1972; Straccia, 2000b) and relies on the fact that 〈α ≥ n〉 and 〈α ≤ m〉 are together inconsistent, if n > 0.5 and m < 0.5. In particular, Straccia (2000b) shows that if Σ and ψ are a normalised fuzzy propositional KB and a query-normalised fuzzy proposition, then Then Σ|≈ψ iff ♯Σ |= ♯ψ.

We will develop a calculus in the style of the constraint propagation method, as this method is usually proposed in the context of DLs (Buchheit et al., 1993a). The calculus extends the fuzzy propositional calculus described by Chen and Kundu (1996) and by Straccia (2000b) to our fuzzy DL case.

We will develop a calculus in the style of the constraint propagation method, as this method is usually proposed in the context of DLs (Buchheit et al., 1993a). The calculus extends the fuzzy propositional calculus described by Chen and Kundu (1996) and by Straccia (2000b) to our fuzzy DL case.
In order to require polynomial space, Schmidt-Schauß and Smolka (1991) introduced the so-called trace rule (T∃) for the ∃ operator.
In the general case, we have to rely on so-called pre-completions (Baader & Hollunder, 1991b; Donini et al., 1994).
Schmidt-Schauß and Smolka (1991) have shown that a set of constraints S = {x:C} is satisfiable iff no trace S of S contains a clash.
✷ How can we check whether for all n > 0 〈a:C ≥ n〉|≈〈a:D ≥ n〉 holds? A solution to this problem, restricted to the propositional case, is given by Straccia (2000a). Indeed, it is shown that
Proposition 6 (Straccia, 2000a) Let p and q be two propositions, 0 < n1 ≤ 0.

Straccia (2000b) has shown that, in case of fuzzy propositional logic, from a set Σ of fuzzy propositions of the form 〈p ≥ n〉 and 〈p ≤ n〉, where p is a proposition, it is possible to determine a finite set NΣ ⊂ [0, 1], where |NΣ| is O(|Σ|), such that glb(Σ, q) ∈ NΣ, i.
Proposition 8 (Straccia, 2000b) Let Σ be a set of fuzzy propositions in NNF and let q be a proposition.
The extension of DLs to the management of vagueness is not new (Tresp & Molitor, 1998; Yen, 1991).
This last idea has been generalised to ALC by Tresp and Molitor (1998) where a certain type of concept modifiers are allowed.

metadata.abstractText: Description Logics (DLs) are suitable, well-known, logics for managing structured knowledge. They allow reasoning about individuals and well defined concepts, i.e. set of individuals with common properties. The experience in using DLs in applications has shown that in many cases we would like to extend their capabilities. In particular, their use in the context of Multimedia Information Retrieval (MIR) leads to the convincement that such DLs should allow the treatment of the inherent imprecision in multimedia object content representation and retrieval. In this paper we will present a fuzzy extension of ALC, combining Zadeh’s fuzzy logic with a classical DL. In particular, concepts becomes fuzzy and, thus, reasoning about imprecise concepts is supported. We will define its syntax, its semantics, describe its properties and present a constraint propagation calculus for reasoning in it.
